com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

saw this video on making your own mixed color filament.
https://youtu.be/nFT4hRy5XhU?t=284
basically just extruding one color filament, then changing the filament to another color, and you can take that printed filament and feed it back in, there's your multi color filament.

and that got me thinking about making your own filament full stop.
there are machines, and videos of people using them, where you grind up old prints or whatever and extrude it into filament. and people have a lot of negative things to say, like the filament size doesn't come out great and so on.
but, if you can print a filament, and then put that filament back in, why couldn't you do that with "grind your own" filament?
big sacks of PLA pellets are cheap as fuck on aliexpress. i guess you wouldn't even need to use a 3d printer, and that's probably how the home machines work, you just draw the melted filament through a nozzle. but you could do it multiple times to smooth out inconsistencies in the first run, if you get what i mean.
i dunno i think there are a bunch of pieces here and it would be reasonable to make your own filament for a couple bucks a kilo with the aliexpress bulk plastic, or if you want to save the planet, grind up your waste prints.

sub: Using natural materials for a workshop?
com: I was thinking about making an open air/half framed workshop thats probably gunna be fairly small. Use it to store my axes, work horse, draw knife and a few other woodworking/farming tools. I have the materials for it, and have worked with natural build materials before for making traditional Anglo-style cottages/hunting cabins. I love the look of them, and I like that I am not using cancerous cardboard with toxic cotton candy foam for insulation. I also like how easy they are to repair if anything goes wrong. Just wondering here, but is there any reason I should go with a more "traditional" workshop?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Im planning a homestead using these buildings. Patrician tier taste

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2519137
I have made a few hunting cabins and guest houses using timber framed cob with adobe/lime plaster. They work really well for the summer and okay for winters. The only thing to watch out for is leaving the sills unprotected/untreated like in my first pic. You also need to know before hand where you are going to hang up heavy objects and plan appropriately. Cob isn't very good for holding heavy objects, but you CAN carve into the walls and make indents for holding items.
If you live in a really cold climate, I highly suggest looking into haybale homes because they insulate a lot better due to being thicker. No, bugs aren't an issue as long as you pack the bales with clay and plaster them properly.

My girlfriend loses her glasses about three times a year. I find them all over the house and in the car. I found them in the trunk once. Also in the top rack of the dishwasher once. Meanwhile I have never lost a pair and I have been wearing them since I was a kid. I have places I put them down; my nightstand, my desk, and the counter in the bathroom for when I am showers. I don't put them anywhere that is not those places. Do the same thing with your tools.

Have designated work areas and storage areas. Similar things should be in the same place. Don't have half your sockets in one toolbox and half in the other, etc. When you are done with a job (or it is on hold) you clean up the area and put shit back where it goes *even if you still need the tools for that job*. When work stops the tools get put away every time. Everything should have its place. That place should be the first place you look for a thing. If you find yourself looking somewhere else first, *move the thing to that place*.

com:
Power, Water, Heating, Cooling, Septic.
What's the best way to handle the big five off-grid?

>Power
Hydro is king, but flowing water is uncommon. Solar is weak and requires several parts that eventually need replacement. When power is abundant you get secondary systems for heating/cooling/etc. This one is hard.

>Water
Rainwater catchment? A water tower or attic water tank for gravity fed water? Maybe an underground cistern so it won't freeze, but then you lack gravity assistance.

>Heating
Can't beat wood. A secondary system should be in place, but a wood stove provides efficient heat and a cooking surface. Easy.

>Cooling
Hardest on the list. There is no simple wood stove-esque equivalent for cooling. Geothermal has promise but it's underpowered and expensive to install.

>Septic
Dead easy. You can put in your own tanks and outhouses just fine.

Wind, solar, and/or stirling engine. You can use a large TV magnifying sheet to create the temperature difference, or tie in a fireplace to amp up the heat difference. Power bank is a necessity.

Rainwater in a catch basin. Military uses chlorine or something for water purification. Look it up.

>Heating.
Refer stirling engine/wind for energy, backup wood stove. Ideally 3 Stirling engines, 3 wind turbines and 3 panels would exist in the setup. Just do the math first.

>Cooling
Check out Persian cooling towers. Temperature control is all about energy transfer. Learn to transform the energy, your heating and cooling will solve itself. You could also use an external wind tunnel setup that directs air down from atmosphere to underground and into your cabin. Do the math, again. Very important.

sub: I need an inexpensive battery backup for sump pumps.
com:
I have a house with a full length rectangular basement. I the top left corner of the basement I have a 1,000 watt sump pump
In the top right corner I have the septic tank pump, 500watts
In the bottom left corner I have the well pump, 3,000 watt
In the same corner I also have a second sump for the basements bathroom, and thats where water soften, and filter flush into. It goes off once a day.
The most important pump to be backed up is the sump, and the septic.
I tried using a 1200 watt UPS on the sump pump, it does not work. Breaks the fuse every time.
I looked at buying HD battery charger, and backup, but thats $1500 in parts and will only work on one side of the basement unless i run a bunch of extension cords, which I dont want to do.
What are my options?
Whole house battery thing like one of those Tesla things? or similar? are there kits for this?
Otherwise is there a sub $300 solution that can run that 1000 watt pump for more than 30 minutes, or something that I can easily add batteries to.
I think I can have the septic pump run off a normal UPS. havnt tried it yet.

your problem is starting current. 1000w pump and a 1200w ups shouldnt pop the breaker. you gots a diff issue.

goddam dude whats the fucking head?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2519268
If you're doing this for occasional power outages, just get a generator and an extension cord. Buy used and fix it up, this could be a couple hundred bucks.

A battery backup is gonna be expensive. Best guess would be somewhere around 900-1200 for the an inverter that can handle the surge watts + battery charger + big copper cables + crimping tools + LiFePO4 battery that can handle that much amperage.

By the time you've done the above, you might as well wire in a couple solar panels and attach the whole thing to your breaker panel, because you've pretty much built the expensive part of a whole home solar system.

>you're polite enough
Yeah, I was gonna be snarky but this is true.
How much air conditioner to buy is the other question. The simple answer is: as much as you can afford. Bigger units are more efficient in general. And you'll run them less often to maintain temperature. (There is such a thing as too much, but it's rare and weird.)
As a VERY rough rule-of-thumb, you want about 30BTU per sq ft. E.g. a 16ftx16ft room is an 9000BTU AC. Or one notch bigger. Or one notch smaller.
>If you have a sliding DOOR, or a fucked-up push out window (I have one), consider getting a unit on rolling casters.
If you do go this route, be sure to get one which has two flexible tubes that go to the door/window. Why? Because the one tube model just exhausts the hot air out, which lowers the air pressure in the room, so every little window leak and vent and whatever you have outside is going to be pouring hot outside air into the room you're trying to cool. Two-tube systems circulate the outside air across the condensing coil and keep pressure normal.

last_replies.name: fixinga OP here
last_replies.com:
>>2517775
nice job anon, make sure u get the same type of cap and ratings...


>>2517799
for de-soldering, I would highly recommend using a solder sucker/pump like a goot GS-108 or TP-100 which will generally work much faster and stress the pads less from my experience especially for someone who never used solder wick b4.
also might want to watch these first before u start if u haven't soldered b4:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL926EC0F1F93C1837

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBXXuFXCtmtqlamIEfu3lSTzM5t1k2cx_

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0wI-5YZQm4

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpgMn88Qfjs

follow the steps and complete the primary check/repair, then you should go for a secondary diagnoses, which has 3 golden roles:

1. during this stage u will have to power up the board, the best way to power it is an isolation transformer, so the board is kept floating (galvanically isolated) this will reduce the risk of electrocution, also install a fast acting low current breaker or an incandescent lightbulb/heater or a fuse inline for added safety against short circuits accidental and otherwise, i personally use a 200w ceramic heater it if it glows i know there is a short and due to the PTC nature of the heater it limits the current enough to not cause catastrophic failure...
u could work on it on that state, but still i wouldn't recommend that for a beginner, so wear gloves and boots while working, and if u don't have access to an isolation transformer u have to use a GFCI/RDC outlet or breaker in line with circuit u are powering:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=olq9wdeNS4c

2.make sure yk where ur hands are!! keep ur hands off the board and the board always powered down at all times except during the test!!!


3. thou shalt check voltages, start from the primary side, since the voltages there are known for the most part, if they are in the ball park (+10v or -10v) its ok, any thing higher u should investigate the primary components

With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. com:
Has anyone installed crown molding before?

I work as a handyman and do mostly paint and drywall. Today a customer asked me to put up some crown molding. I said sure. After 2 hours and like 5 missed cuts, I just gave up and told the customer I could not do it.

Anyone worked with this shit? How do you get this thing down?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518630
I do cabinets. Most of these get crown and light rail. I came up through several other carpentry positions to get into the higher detail work. I was on crews that wouldn't let me touch a stick of crown, but they were happy to send me up a ladder with sandpaper to fix their cuts.

I always think of this song
https://youtu.be/ujmGiBl36f8
Crown is cut Upside Down and Backwards. It is important that you rest the crown correctly against your miter fence. You'll notice that it rocks against the fence and base, so I generally make the start of the cut or installed physical bottom of the crown piece flat against the fence because your angle will change if it's not.

Cabs are good to start because they're clean boxes to wrap. If you're touching ceilings and walls, especially on an old house, you know what you're getting into. They're going to be up and down across the span. They're not going to be right angles. It will often be worth your time to cope the crown like the OP image because coping gives you more angle of acceptable installation. On really ugly ceilings, you might end up scribing the top edge of the crown then adjusting the height by bringing spots down with a belt sander or free handing on the table saw.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518641
It's carpentry, not handywork. Get gud, simple as.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>After 2 hours and like 5 missed cuts, I just gave up and told the customer I could not do it.
>>2518641
>had to tell the customer i couldn't do it and ended up just doing the other stuff they wanted done
Ya know, credit to you guys. Too many others would fuck it up and try to bullshit their way out of it.
Most of the answer is in building a good mitre box and using s lot of clamps to hold the piece in there.
The one depicted in >>2518644 is traditional. But for moulding you also want a 45° that rises parallel to the flat this will put a 45° bevel on both pieces so that the patter meets itself between them. So special sawing. And if the walls aren't properly square, it's easy enough to fill and paint over the narrow gap.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Like the one at the end here. Both pieces get that cut. So they kiss in the corner. Bridge any gap that might appear.
Also, a tip: do those corners first. It's much easier to straight trim a piece of moulding in the middle of the wall than to play games in the corners.

com:
I've been having problems with muddy water in my ponds, when it rains it gets even worse. I get the water from a small river through gravity, the pipe is just submersed in it so there isn't any kind of filtration whatsoever. I am wondering if placing a layer of rock, clay pebbles or anything that would let the water through while keeping solids out would be a solution to this.

I know of the chemical treatments I could use to settle these solids but I don't want to use them, I've also been to fisheries that use huge sedimentation tanks to solve this. The setup I am thinking about doing is a dam with 3 walls which one would be porous and would filter the water that the pipe would then discharge in my ponds, the overflow would let branches and other debris continue down the river. Would the water still be muddy after this? I also know this works for people that make a series of filtration layers (rock, sand, charcoal, etc) for drinking water but the flow I need is considerable, so I can't have a trickle.

If it did work I would imagine I would need to clean it periodically but that wouldn't be a problem.
filename: collection of water from muddy river

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Might be easier to just keep it muddy and clean your pool more often. Doubt the mid is bad for your fish.
You can use filters, but they will get clogged if you need a considerable flow. Damming will slow the water and allow sedimentation to happen.
The dam overflow will the be much cleaner. Triple dam even more do, but you'll end up having to clean your dams.

Look into rain gardens and sediment retention; Geosyntec has some documents regarding volume inflow reduction from geo engineering with rain gardens or bioengineered strata like you mentioned, both reduce sediment deposition by stabilizing the banks, please avoid chemical treatments if you can, and try some decorative shrubbery, cattails and lily pads, water demanding plants, and thin trees, you can even trim these regularly and the effect will still be observed. I can come back with some more resources but general keywords for more info would be the ones mentioned above as well as any study relating vegetation to reductions in watershed sediment load, retention ponding, and erosion or stream bank stabilization. I try to salvage all components, that have honestly saved me a fortune, some of my more complex projects used mosfets and h-bridge and even Z80 chips that are almost 50SARs (13.30USD) here, i think i mentioned this b4 but all the caps I used i got from an old trashed amp, most modern electronic components are fairly resilient and can handle moderate heat (100c-350c) in short intervals just fine, but i wouldn't say the same about board substrate, especially the older boards which use cotton paper resin composite or phenolic resins which really don't like the temperature getting above 380c for too long as they tend to puff up or crack or burn.
personally i use a manual solder pump and wick for most salvage work to not stress the board or component, but for stuff i really don't want to damage i have a a goot TP-100 de-soldering gun that I use for that stuff, its not ideal but at least i have some temperature control that I don't have with my soldering iron which tends to drift up as i am working from (~345c-430c) or even higher if not used for some time a while plugged in, which is usually not a problem when i am de-soldering for salvaging and idc about the pcb, but during rework it tents to be a pain to work around, a wet sponge helps knock the temp down 10 or so degrees but it is really hard to gauge the temp without constantly checking it with thermocouple. my iron is gr8 60% of the time when i am doing anything else, but just makes my life a nightmare in that other 40%(which is rework), it is a goot TQ-95 for reference.

name: Anonymous
com:
How would I go about making my own cases, keycaps, buttons, and switches with printed lettering, logos, etc. for my electronics projects (a handheld computer, for example)? I want to have a similar level of quality to at least 1980s consumer products, not perfect but at least good looking and robust.

A 3D printer would be an obvious starting point, but some of the particulars like the brushed aluminum surfacing or a folded sheet metal case would require different tools and processes. What are some tools I'd need, and what processes would be required to achieve this kind of build quality?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
For more "quality" fit-and-finish like brushed aluminum surfaces or that calculator you posted; the calculator's case is stamped aluminum, a process too costly in tooling to make economical for small projects. It is also why nearly everything is injection molded plastic cases today. You can look at laser or water jet cutting thin plates of brushed aluminum as a type of manufacturing for a panel or enclosure face.

If you want to really get into crazy DIY rabbit hole expertise, check out Ben Krasnow's "Applied Science" channel on youtube.

Good luck anon, I hope the best success for your projects, post results sometime.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518654
>>2518656
>>2518658
I'm in Australia, so sourcing stuff like keycaps and silicone might be a bit trickier, but I'll see what I can find.

For the metal fabrication I could probably work with what I've got in my shed, but the main question I need an answer to is how manufacturers put text and logos on their products? Is there a specific process that can be done at home to achieve the same results?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518734
Silicone can be hard to get text and logos to stay on if done in fine detail by hand. You would have to find a silicon bonding paint or dye and then paint the reverse image in the mold and then pour over it, which might give some results you could try to refine.

You may be better off looking into labelling the faceplate of the button/switch/key/housing. In that case you can look at water transfer decals with a finishing coat (polyurethane?) to protect from rubbing off, silkscreening (lots of color choices), or laser engraving and then wiping in a color inlay in the etching (good for single color). Each different method has increased costs in tooling. "Applied Science" has a silkscreening video, and also you can see what "DIY silkscreen electronics" search yields.

Silkscreen is sometimes taught at community or continuing education centers, or whatever the equivalent might be called in Australia. Laser engravers are not too expensive depending on what you want. I've never done water decals on a finished product other than model airplanes/cars etc. but they are legitimately used in small batch productions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518734
Also, if you are having trouble sourcing silicone mix materials, try looking in your country's film industry sector; many of the silicone suppliers sell to that business because silicone, moldable foams, urethanes, polymer clay, etc. is used extensively in the film industry for prop making and character creation. Just a largely overlooked but super-specific niche DIY market to make fake items that look real for film.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518599
Made some cases:
If plastics are okay, then vacuum form from acrylic or other sheet. It’s a really easy process and diy suitable, you just need a die that’s cnc cut or 3D printed.

For metal cases if you have an adequate press rubber pressing and stamping/punching is doable. You do need punches/dies. Standard shaped punches can be bought, but the dies for rubber pressing and stamping need to be CNC’d or otherwise manufactured from steel. For simple rectangular case an angle grinder could work though

sub: How can I be sure this is tinned copper?
com:
My autism is making me paranoid. Today I received this 10AWG tinned copper silicone wire from Aliexpress. The reviews are good, the core/insulation measurements match or even outmatch the specs but you'll always get some retards in the reviews saying that this is not real tinned copper and that it's aluminium, silver, brass or whatever. But what if those retards are actually the smart ones and all the others got fooled?

Here is what I've done so far:
-Burned the shit out of some strands. Nothing gets brittle. Only thing that melts is the end of some of the strands, once they're cooled down they form a small ball at the end of the strand. Overall after many burns the conductor hasn't lost its thickness whatsoever.
-The burning definitely reveals some orange colors on the strands. You also get some yellowish and even greenish/blueish tints sometimes. Will post some shitty pics bellow.
-Scrapping strands with a knife doesn't reveal shit because they're just too small.
-Checked with my multimeter and I get 000.1Ω from one 5m wire but from what I understand this doesn't necessarily mean anything. Ideally you need a "4-wire measurement" thingy and I don't have one.
-Not the main subject but it's definitely silicone insulation, smells like shit out of the box and hasn't melted one bit from all my burning tests.

Overall it seems legit but I'm just asking you smarter autists just to be sure. Could it be anything else than copper? What if some strands are legit copper but some are not and Chinaman is trying to outsmart me? I'M TURNING INSANE.

>Why don't you order something from your country if you're so paranoid
All the highly flexible silicone tinned copper wires for sale here seem to be imported from China anyway lol, might as well get a better price and order from AE.

last_replies.com:
>>2516694
It's old, corroded copper in new silicone tubing. How much you paid for it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2517477

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>Checked with my multimeter and I get 000.1Ω from one 5m wire but from what I understand this doesn't necessarily mean anything. Ideally you need a "4-wire measurement" thingy and I don't have one.
I don't know what that retard was talking about, but the multimeter test is fine. Resistance is the only metric you care about.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2517299

Brass wire is phenomenally rare to begin with. I've never even seen any. Outside of the stuff sold for jewelry, I have no idea what you'd use it for, even.

>>2518267
>but the multimeter test is fine

Multimeters are not accurate at low resistances. Anything lower than 1-2Ω should usually be treated as just a ballpark measurement, never even mind measurements below 100mΩ. You usually need a dedicated resistance meter for that kind of measurement, or to measure voltage across test points when using a constant-current source (which is what a resistance meter does, just with convenient packaging).

com: I found out my local butcher sells sheep heads. How do I go about cleaning one? Guides online say all I have to do is boil, scour, and soak in bleach. Are there other ways that don't require the special beetles? I'm afraid steps one and three of the Alaskan gov's guide, boiling and bleaching, will weaken the bone. Step two will leave marks, no? Has anyone gone about this before and has tips? I want to adorn my wall with a sheep's skull like Neolithic villagers in the Zagros. pic unrelated

last_replies.com: ITT idiots

>>2518105

>>2518091
Can't let nature take its course, I live in a big city and it's icy winter right now.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518114
You don't want to boil because it weakens the bones. You cannot get good specimens doing that. You can buy some beetles and a tank or you could set the head outside on a balcony or something inside a mesh cage and let maggots eat some. For the water bucket putrefaction step you also want to set the bucket outside on a balcony or something. This really stinks. The whole process really smells. Don't do this inside your house or in an apartment. Wait for warmer weather. You will have trouble getting the death smell out of your home. Trying to think of how to change the water buckets without defiling your apartment. You may very well get the cops called on you or lose your lease for this. This is an outdoor activity.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you live in the city, you're going to have problems.

The best way would be to use a combination of what people above have mentioned. Find somewhere where you can leave it for a few weeks and let nature take its course. Obviously it needs to be secured to stop larger predators taking it. After most of the flesh etc. is gone, you want to soak it in a bucket of water for a while to get into all the nooks and crannies. Adding a small amount of dish soap will help things along. Take it out and give it a good scrub and change the water every week or so. At this stage the teeth may potentially come loose so make sure you don't loose any. The dish soap is essential for degreasing the bones. To get a nice white finish, soak them in a 1:3 mixture of hydrogen peroxide to water.

Under no circumstances boil them as this will only trap the fat inside the bone and make them rot and smell. It also undermines the structural integrity of the bone. Also never use bleach as this will also weaken the bone structure.

Finally join a Facebook group for bone collectors or taxidermists. There are lot's of great communities that are happy help and will teach you a thing or two.

com: Does anyone know what TheBackyardScientist is using as solid rocket fuel in his latest video? Im not trying to do anything harmful just curious.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2515777
Potassium nitrate isn't hard to produce. That's why it was in the original recipe for gunpowder. You can even make and purify it from scratch.

Potash can be produced by soaking wood ashes in water to make an impure potassium carbonate solution. Nitrates can be produced by giving microbes time to act on urine in sandy dirt. Potassium ions from potassium carbonate have a superior affinity for nitrate ions from mixed nitrates in soil, so you can easily grow pure potassium nitrate crystals by fractional crystallization from solutions in water.

I don't know about any laws about making it, especially in Europe, but from a practical perspective rather than a legal one, it's feasible to produce limited amounts of KNO3 if you have some suitable workspace. You can make larger amounts with animal manure, though urine seems cleaner and easier to work with.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518027
To be clear, you can make quite a lot of potassium nitrate from your own urine. Nearly all of the nitrogen in protein you eat will end up in your urine, and be converted to nitrate by microbes if you're pissing in the sandbox.

If you eat 100g of protein daily, about 16g of that will be nitrogen, so if you get half your urine in the box, that'll be 8g of nitrogen per day. Nitrogen is about 1/7th the weight of potassium nitrate, so that gives 56g of potassium nitrate per day. Accounting for other losses, you can probably realistically produce about a pound of potassium nitrate every two weeks from your own urine, or a pound every week if you really go hard.

That's a whole lot of model rocket propellant or gunpowder for personal use.

there's 3 uses of planing

1) scrubbing: removing large amounts of material off the wood's surface
2) flattening: making the surface flat
3) smoothing: making the surface smooth

The third use is a substitute for sanding and his how they did it before sandpaper become widely used. The positives are that it's very quick, efficient and even enjoyable. The downside is the large upfront cost (or time investment if you buy an antique one) and the skill required to do it well.

com: I want to convert one 3-wire, 220 V circuit to two 2-wire 120 V circuits. I want to use the existing 220 V wiring from the main junction box to the old outlet box and then run new 12 gauge wire to the two new 120 V circuits. Since the existing 220 V circuit isn’t grounded, I am going to use GFCI outlets in the 120 V circuits. I will replace the ganged 20A circuit breakers at the main junction box with two single 20A breakers. Does DIY have suggested changes?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2516154
I wonder if the GFCI manufacturers have any influence on the people who write the Code in the same way the drug manufacturers influence what goes into the DSM.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514670
>I will replace the ganged 20A circuit breakers at the main junction box with two single 20A breakers.

Don't. Feed both 120V circuits from a 2 pole breaker. Two reasons 1) someone working on one leg won't open one breaker and back feed a neutral from the other side. 2) This will ensure that the two legs are fed from opposite sides of the 240 V. This will keep the neutral current below that of either leg. If not, someone might move a breaker in the future and put 40A on the common neutral. 3) It's code.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514681
>Add a vernier readout and you can easily exceed the precision of most off-the-shelf measuring tools.

You are confusing "precision" and "resolution". You cannot get actual precision/accuracy out of this arrangement that exceeds that of the screws you used to make it. If it were that easy, actual micrometers would get away with using a rolled differential screw. In reality, even cheap micrometers just use a single, ground screw.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2517016
No. Rolled screws are surprisingly precise. They have to be or the whole "interchangeable parts" thing wouldn't work. You wouldn't be able to thread a nut all the way down a 36" piece of all-thread without it jamming. Now, are they precisely *linear*? No. They have repeating cycles of error for every X distance, where X is based on the exact tooling used. But that is easily worked around in a DIY measuring tool with calibration tests and a custom scribed scale. And cheap micrometers use a single ground screw because... surprise... it's cheaper. The economics of mass production greatly favor spending a tiny bit more on the screw vs. doing a custom calibrated scale for each unit.
>You cannot get actual precision/accuracy out of this arrangement that exceeds that of the screws you used to make it.
If that was true we would have no precision tools at all, since the first precision tools had to be created by hand at some point. In order to build the first micrometer, they had to overcome the imprecision of crudely cut threads. And it turns out that one good way to do this was... the differential screw.

com:
I know you're supposed to just put pavers right into the dirt but is it fine if I intend to redo it properly in a year? The worst that can happen is that the bricks just get a bit uneven right?

Alternatively: what's the laziest way to make a garden path?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Pavers right on dirt will move and be unlevel almost immediately. Also it’s a huge pain in the ass to scrape all the mud and crap off each individual one when you go to do it right.
Larger flag stones won’t shift as easy but still the same problem with becoming unlevel over time. Also huge pain to level dirt. Much easier to just dig down a little bit, put down sharp sand, compact and screed, then lay the flagstones.
Pavers will need something to retain them like in your picture, I prefer concrete around them once laid.
If there will be heavy stuff like cars on it, you’ll need to dig deeper, put down road base, compact (ideally with a powered compactor) then thin layer of sharp sand, compact again, screed and lay. Too shallow a back fill or not enough compacting and it will get ruts.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Tossed some pavers the few feet I needed to get to the gravel. Works fine run em over often enough doesn't mess em up.

I’m simple term. Gut the interior walls and add insulation and replaster the walls.

I’m in nz, My house was built 1891.

Timber two storey, had existing new ceiling and underfloor insulation.

I did look at getting those guys around to drill holes in the walls and spray insulation in between each stud. Cost to much.

Watch this video, this is what we do here.
https://youtu.be/CxP14Huwd0k


So I just went one room at a time and ripped the linings off the walls, put a damp proof course wrap between each stud, used a pneumatic staple gun. and put decent insulation on top of that. Then relined the walls with plasterboard.

Protip: if you’re looking at budget compressors, they’re not going to run most air tools like 1/2” impact wrenches all that well.

You can get one with the pressure, but that won’t matter when the pressure drops to 70psi at the tank within a couple seconds and the pump can’t keep up.

Real shop air tools require a lot of air, not <30gal consumer compressors that are good for nail guns and filling up tires.

This. Bought a 30gal compressor a few years back with the same goal of running my impact + some other automotive tools - not great, nigh unusable. Got a cordless 1/2" impact and it's been great. The cost of setting up a truly good air compressor and running hoses all over your workshop is in all likelihood not worth it, and if you cheap out on anything you'll be sorely dissapointed. Go with electric if you just want to run a few tools, corded or cordless based on what you are doing.
